speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: You shall not now be stol'n, you have locks upon you;

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: So graze as you find pasture.

speaker: Second Gaoler
text_entry: Ay, or a stomach.

speaker: Second Gaoler
text_entry: Exeunt Gaolers

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: Most welcome, bondage! for thou art away,

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: think, to liberty: yet am I better

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: Than one that's sick o' the gout; since he had rather

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: Groan so in perpetuity than be cured

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: By the sure physician, death, who is the key

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: To unbar these locks. My conscience, thou art fetter'd

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: More than my shanks and wrists: you good gods, give me

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: The penitent instrument to pick that bolt,

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: Then, free for ever! Is't enough I am sorry?

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: So children temporal fathers do appease;

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: Gods are more full of mercy. Must I repent?

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: I cannot do it better than in gyves,

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: Desired more than constrain'd: to satisfy,

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: If of my freedom 'tis the main part, take

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: No stricter render of me than my all.

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: I know you are more clement than vile men,

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: Who of their broken debtors take a third,

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: A sixth, a tenth, letting them thrive again

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: On their abatement: that's not my desire:

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: For Imogen's dear life take mine; and though

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: 'Tis not so dear, yet 'tis a life; you coin'd it:

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: 'Tween man and man they weigh not every stamp;

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: Though light, take pieces for the figure's sake:

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: You rather mine, being yours: and so, great powers,

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: If you will take this audit, take this life,

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: And cancel these cold bonds. O Imogen!

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: I'll speak to thee in silence.

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: Sleeps

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: Solemn music. Enter, as in an apparition,  SICILIUS LEONATUS, father to Posthumus Leonatus,  an old man, attired like a warrior; leading in  his hand an ancient matron, his wife, and mother  to Posthumus Leonatus, with music before them:  then, after other music, follow the two young  Leonati, brothers to Posthumus Leonatus, with  wounds as they died in the wars. They circle Posthumus Leonatus round, as he lies sleeping

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: No more, thou thunder-master, show

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Thy spite on mortal flies:

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: With Mars fall out, with Juno chide,

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: That thy adulteries

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Rates and revenges.

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Hath my poor boy done aught but well,

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Whose face I never saw?

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: I died whilst in the womb he stay'd

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Attending nature's law:

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Whose father then, as men report

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Thou orphans' father art,

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Thou shouldst have been, and shielded him

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: From this earth-vexing smart.

speaker: Mother
text_entry: Lucina lent not me her aid,

speaker: Mother
text_entry: But took me in my throes;

speaker: Mother
text_entry: That from me was Posthumus ript,

speaker: Mother
text_entry: Came crying 'mongst his foes,

speaker: Mother
text_entry: A thing of pity!

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Great nature, like his ancestry,

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Moulded the stuff so fair,

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: That he deserved the praise o' the world,

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: As great Sicilius' heir.

speaker: First Brother
text_entry: When once he was mature for man,

speaker: First Brother
text_entry: In Britain where was he

speaker: First Brother
text_entry: That could stand up his parallel;

speaker: First Brother
text_entry: Or fruitful object be

speaker: First Brother
text_entry: In eye of Imogen, that best

speaker: First Brother
text_entry: Could deem his dignity?

speaker: Mother
text_entry: With marriage wherefore was he mock'd,

speaker: Mother
text_entry: To be exiled, and thrown

speaker: Mother
text_entry: From Leonati seat, and cast

speaker: Mother
text_entry: From her his dearest one,

speaker: Mother
text_entry: Sweet Imogen?

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Why did you suffer Iachimo,

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Slight thing of Italy,

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: To taint his nobler heart and brain

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: With needless jealosy;

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: And to become the geck and scorn

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: O' th' other's villany?

speaker: Second Brother
text_entry: For this from stiller seats we came,

speaker: Second Brother
text_entry: Our parents and us twain,

speaker: Second Brother
text_entry: That striking in our country's cause

speaker: Second Brother
text_entry: Fell bravely and were slain,

speaker: Second Brother
text_entry: Our fealty and Tenantius' right

speaker: Second Brother
text_entry: With honour to maintain.

speaker: First Brother
text_entry: Like hardiment Posthumus hath

speaker: First Brother
text_entry: To Cymbeline perform'd:

speaker: First Brother
text_entry: Then, Jupiter, thou king of gods,

speaker: First Brother
text_entry: Why hast thou thus adjourn'd

speaker: First Brother
text_entry: The graces for his merits due,

speaker: First Brother
text_entry: Being all to dolours turn'd?

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Thy crystal window ope; look out;

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: No longer exercise

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Upon a valiant race thy harsh

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: And potent injuries.

speaker: Mother
text_entry: Since, Jupiter, our son is good,

speaker: Mother
text_entry: Take off his miseries.

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Peep through thy marble mansion; help;

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Or we poor ghosts will cry

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: To the shining synod of the rest

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Against thy deity.

speaker: Second Brother
text_entry: Help, Jupiter; or we appeal,

speaker: Second Brother
text_entry: And from thy justice fly.

speaker: Second Brother
text_entry: Jupiter descends in thunder and lightning, sitting  upon an eagle: he throws a thunderbolt. The Apparitions fall on their knees

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: No more, you petty spirits of region low,

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: Offend our hearing; hush! How dare you ghosts

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: Accuse the thunderer, whose bolt, you know,

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: Sky-planted batters all rebelling coasts?

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: Poor shadows of Elysium, hence, and rest

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: Upon your never-withering banks of flowers:

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: Be not with mortal accidents opprest;

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: No care of yours it is; you know 'tis ours.

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: Whom best I love I cross; to make my gift,

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: The more delay'd, delighted. Be content;

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: Your low-laid son our godhead will uplift:

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: His comforts thrive, his trials well are spent.

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: Our Jovial star reign'd at his birth, and in

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: Our temple was he married. Rise, and fade.

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: He shall be lord of lady Imogen,

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: And happier much by his affliction made.

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: This tablet lay upon his breast, wherein

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: Our pleasure his full fortune doth confine:

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: and so, away: no further with your din

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: Express impatience, lest you stir up mine.

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: Mount, eagle, to my palace crystalline.

speaker: Jupiter
text_entry: Ascends

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: He came in thunder; his celestial breath

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Was sulphurous to smell: the holy eagle

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Stoop'd as to foot us: his ascension is

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: More sweet than our blest fields: his royal bird

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Prunes the immortal wing and cloys his beak,

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: As when his god is pleased.

speaker: All
text_entry: Thanks, Jupiter!

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: The marble pavement closes, he is enter'd

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: His radiant root. Away! and, to be blest,

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: Let us with care perform his great behest.

speaker: Sicilius Leonatus
text_entry: The Apparitions vanish

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: [Waking]  Sleep, thou hast been a grandsire, and begot

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: A father to me; and thou hast created

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: A mother and two brothers: but, O scorn!

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: Gone! they went hence so soon as they were born:

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: And so I am awake. Poor wretches that depend

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: On greatness' favour dream as I have done,

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: Wake and find nothing. But, alas, I swerve:

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: Many dream not to find, neither deserve,

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: And yet are steep'd in favours: so am I,

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: That have this golden chance and know not why.

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: What fairies haunt this ground? A book? O rare one!

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: Be not, as is our fangled world, a garment

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: Nobler than that it covers: let thy effects

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: So follow, to be most unlike our courtiers,

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: As good as promise.

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: Reads

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: 'When as a lion's whelp shall, to himself unknown,

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: without seeking find, and be embraced by a piece of

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: tender air; and when from a stately cedar shall be

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: lopped branches, which, being dead many years,

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: shall after revive, be jointed to the old stock and

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: freshly grow; then shall Posthumus end his miseries,

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: Britain be fortunate and flourish in peace and plenty.'

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: 'Tis still a dream, or else such stuff as madmen

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: Tongue and brain not; either both or nothing;

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: Or senseless speaking or a speaking such

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: As sense cannot untie. Be what it is,

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: The action of my life is like it, which

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: I'll keep, if but for sympathy.

speaker: Posthumus Leonatus
text_entry: Re-enter First Gaoler

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: Come, sir, are you ready for death?

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: Over-roasted rather; ready long ago.

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: Hanging is the word, sir: if

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: you be ready for that, you are well cooked.

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: So, if I prove a good repast to the

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: spectators, the dish pays the shot.

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: A heavy reckoning for you, sir. But the comfort is,

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: you shall be called to no more payments, fear no

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: more tavern-bills; which are often the sadness of

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: parting, as the procuring of mirth: you come in

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: flint for want of meat, depart reeling with too

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: much drink; sorry that you have paid too much, and

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: sorry that you are paid too much; purse and brain

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: both empty; the brain the heavier for being too

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: light, the purse too light, being drawn of

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: heaviness: of this contradiction you shall now be

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: quit. O, the charity of a penny cord! It sums up

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: thousands in a trice: you have no true debitor and

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: creditor but it; of what's past, is, and to come,

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: the discharge: your neck, sir, is pen, book and

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: counters; so the acquittance follows.

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: I am merrier to die than thou art to live.

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: Indeed, sir, he that sleeps feels not the

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: tooth-ache: but a man that were to sleep your

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: sleep, and a hangman to help him to bed, I think he

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: would change places with his officer; for, look you,

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: sir, you know not which way you shall go.

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: Yes, indeed do I, fellow.

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: Your death has eyes in 's head then; I have not seen

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: him so pictured: you must either be directed by

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: some that take upon them to know, or do take upon

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: yourself that which I am sure you do not know, or

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: jump the after inquiry on your own peril: and how

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: you shall speed in your journey's end, I think you'll

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: never return to tell one.

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: I tell thee, fellow, there are none want eyes to

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: direct them the way I am going, but such as wink and

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: will not use them.

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: What an infinite mock is this, that a man should

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: have the best use of eyes to see the way of

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: blindness! I am sure hanging's the way of winking.

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Knock off his manacles; bring your prisoner to the king.

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: Thou bring'st good news; I am called to be made free.

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: I'll be hang'd then.

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: Thou shalt be then freer than a gaoler; no bolts for the dead.

speaker: POSTHUMUS LEONATUS
text_entry: Exeunt POSTHUMUS LEONATUS and Messenger

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: Unless a man would marry a gallows and beget young

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: gibbets, I never saw one so prone. Yet, on my

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: conscience, there are verier knaves desire to live,

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: for all he be a Roman: and there be some of them

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: too that die against their wills; so should I, if I

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: were one. I would we were all of one mind, and one

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: mind good; O, there were desolation of gaolers and

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: gallowses! I speak against my present profit, but

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: my wish hath a preferment in 't.

speaker: First Gaoler
text_entry: Exeunt
